text: [Applause]
this American airstrike near the Syrian
Turkish border had one key target oil in
a small town called tal of yad in Syria
an Isis oil refinery was hit by the
attack the plant was likely processing
crude oil from one of the several fields
that Isis now controls in Iraq and Syria
all told black market oil feeds an
estimated 1 million dollars a day to the
Islamic states coffers Isis control of
oil is an essential aspect of their
financing and their logistical support
Iraq's oil black market goes back
decades facing UN sanctions Saddam
Hussein encouraged individuals to
smuggle oil and it became normal for
people to personally own tanker trucks
and in this archival footage trucks
carrying basic dry goods like flour have
custom undercarriages equipped for
transporting oil being able to sell a
tanker of oil for several thousand
dollars of pure profit is a huge
incentive to do something something
dangerous turkey has always been one of
the main paths for oil smugglers because
it's a natural port so if you can get
the oil as far as turkey you can then
get it to move on to the European
markets during the American occupation
of Iraq al Qaeda ran the smuggling
routes again relying on regular Iraqis
today Isis has inherited them
and even as Turkey cracks down hard on
smuggling from Isis territories the
terrorist group still has power in
pricing the oil a barrel of oil
originally sold by Isis for $25 can sell
for around $70 on the international
market covering the cost of bribes and
still ensuring a profit
so if $25 a barrel wasn't doing it hey
why not 15 Isis still gets to make money
but now the economic incentives are even
greater for the drivers and the
middlemen the border guards and buyers
to look the other way or to participate
in financing a terrorist organization
the question is how low will Isis allow
the prices to go and what risks are
drivers willing to take one of the easy
solutions here for the United States and
its allies would simply do be to blow up
these trucks on their way to Turkey
American officials have been reluctant
to do that so far and they've been
reluctant because it's not clear that
the truck drivers themselves who would
be killed in such an attack are
themselves members of Isis
while that debate continues airstrikes
on Isis oil refineries have had some
effect by striking these types of
facilities we reduce their ability to
generate the funds and the fuel required
to sustain their operations no matter
how much crude Isis controls if they
don't have anywhere to refine it and
they don't have anywhere to sell it then
it becomes almost useless to them now
Isis is growing desperate for fuel there
are reports they are digging pits in the
ground filling them with oil and
lighting them on fire clearly a very
crude way to refine the oil and along
the border of Isis territories border
guards are being bribed with thousands
of dollars to allow trucks loaded with
fuel to come back into Isis territories
the important thing here is that this
indicates that there's a really strong
demand for fuel in Isis territory which
also indicates a shortage of fuel in
Isis territory
Isis has grander ambitions it actually
wants to control territory that also
means though they're responsible for
providing for the people in that
territory and that means they need fuel
so if you can deprive Isis of their fuel
you can deprive them of their ability in
many ways to administer one of the basic
needs of the state
